Are Small Custom Website Application Development Businesses Viable Anymore?

Posted by davidhayden on July 28, 2007

I was sitting on the lanai with my wife after another busy week and noticed we were both fantasizing about the same thing – sleep and watching a good movie :) We started reminiscing about the days before life seemed to get complicated, hectic, and full of responsibilities.


We realized it would be really easy to blame our lack of sleep and free time on our 3 wonderful children, but the truth is that we have completely spread our time really thin with 2 demanding careers and a wholesale green tea business.


It got me thinking that something is totally wrong with our lifestyles when our fantasies are about sleep and being able to watch TV


So… Part I of my master plan was to sell our wholesale green tea business, which was successfully completed this week. Although I am happy about the reduction in responsibility, I now have to think of another way to support my expensive green tea habit, but that is another story altogether


Part II of this master plan may be to get back to a life that I enjoyed several years back of doing custom web application development that was mainly centered around various e-commerce, content management system, document processing, job tracking, real-estate, and various other frameworks that I had built over time. In my little spare time over the past few years I have also added a simple blogging, forums, and active record framework to the mix.


The question is, however, is the market saturated with small, custom development firms such that one could even make a decent living? Are there too many highschool students, college students, and international businesses armed with code generators making it impossible for an experienced developer to eek out a living? My guess is yes, but I think this would make a good social experiment just for kicks.


My goal over the next month is to start a small custom web application development business and blog about my progress and challenges. I have already scheduled a trip to my lawyer next week to see how we handle this for tax and legal purposes, but after that my marketing director, wife, will come up with a catchy name for the business. We will then create the business, register a domain name, create a website, and then proceed from there.


My guess is that all of this will make for some interesting blogging. Whether or not it will be a successful venture remains to be seen, so I won’t completely quit my day job As an FYI, I made need some help with project work if we get some customers!


More on this later…

10 Responses to Are Small Custom Website Application Development Businesses Viable Anymore?

  1. Joe Healy says:
    August 10, 2007 at 3:15 pm

    Hookup with KeithK. He’s always looking for someone to sub work to.

  2. Brian says:
    August 6, 2007 at 6:54 pm

    A little over three years ago, I left a good-paying stable job at a large law firm to go into independent consulting. (Side note: I did this three months before my wife had our first child and she became a stay-at-home mom. Bad timing on going independent, but it worked. Read on…)

    There is PLENTY of work out there. I found more than I could do for a good period of time without looking very hard. One client grew from a small project to one who provided over 50% of my income, and allowed me to hire a second person as a contractor for about a year.

    The competition is often overpriced and qualified (large consulting firms) or underpriced and underqualified (the underqualified people who respond to Craig’s List and similar postings and underbid people like me). The good part is that once you get a foothold people see the value of competence. Smart clients are willing to pay the right price for quality work. A client who complains at this isn’t worth taking on as a client.

    All that being said, I ended the full-time independent consulting thing when I got a once-in-a-lifetime job offer. I still do side consulting, and I have more work than I have time to do, which shows that I’d have no problem continuing the independent route if I did. I could have more side work than I take on, too.

    That being said — if you need some supplemental work, or need help with your work, let me know. At some point, I may get a lead on a good project that I can’t do myself; OR, I may reach a point where I don’t have side work but could use the extra income (and experience)…

  3. David Hayden says:
    July 30, 2007 at 5:12 pm

    I love tool sets like, Django, which were harvested from real projects and needs. I have used MonoRail quite a bit, so I see tools like these being indispensible.

    I think this is where code generation plays a role, too, when applications get much more opinionated and don’t need to adapt to as many variables.

    I didn’t realize how much I missed this type of development I think the change will do me some good and open my eyes to some new tools and practices.

  4. Stephen R says:
    July 30, 2007 at 3:24 pm

    The tool sets can definitely change. The smaller the project the less time you want to invest in it. Someone above mentioned Django, which is a good web framework. If you’re only building the software for the web you can throw out a lot of the normal component reusability aspects.

  5. David Hayden says:
    July 30, 2007 at 2:10 pm

    That’s good to know, Dan.

    I think juggling multiple small projects is probably important. The nice thing, too, is that you can continue working on another project if you need to wait for client feedback on others.

    Thinking out loud… I am wondering if the types of tools and perhaps programming language choices change when developing small projects.

  6. Dan says:
    July 30, 2007 at 1:37 am

    Absolutely viable. I work for a small consulting firm that does all types of application development, and we have one guy who solely focuses on website development for small businesses. He is able to juggle multiple small projects each with billings ranging from 3K to 5K, and easily justifies his salary. You need to focus on networking and selling yourself, and from the sound of it, you already have a stable client-base that can serve as excellent references. You can easily take business away from the amateurs and rent-a-coders .

    Good luck!

  7. David Hayden says:
    July 28, 2007 at 2:26 pm

    Thanks Guys.

    Just to be clear, I currently have a successful consulting business that does a lot of custom development work, but this is larger-scale stuff that is just really demanding and keeps me from enjoying more time with my family. It is especially painful as a part-time stay-at-home Dad.

    It is apparent that I can no longer try to balance the larger scale projects and live a family-oriented lifestyle without burning the candle at both ends – at least until all of my children are in school

    I want to see if I can get back to my roots, which is running a custom web development company that focuses more on small-to-medium projects, training, and mentoring. I remember the lifestyle being much easier, but we it was a little less competitive at the time.

    We’ll see…

  8. Lorenzo says:
    July 28, 2007 at 2:05 pm

    Yes, there is still space for quality stuff. Try posting smt on Guru.com, Rentacoder and the like and probably to no surprise, the quality of the applicants is extremly low: they work on the cheap but 99% of the time you get what you pay for. There’s a few bright stars earning a living on these sites making good stuff, for which of course they charge more.

    As for frameworks well, i don’t want to start a flamewar here, but a good hacker with a good knowledge of Python and Django can run circles around a C# hacker with all his toolsets of code-generators and mini-frameworks.
